Presumably, you eventually want some of your edits to sync with someone else's changes. The really cool thing about
is that multiple authors, can work on the same content of a plugin, for the same

only to realize two seconds later that you needed to make a change and then renamed your document to "

If you can relate, then you know the initial problem version control set out to solve over 50 years ago. On a fundamental level, all

If you mess something up, or need to revisit an earlier point of edits, you can always hop back in time to that checkpoint. You've likely experienced versioning features in applications like Google Docs, Microsoft Word, Notion, or even Figma.
While many applications have a sense of versioning, to get precise synchronization results we have to have a slightly
erent mental model of what a document really is. When we edited "
Prior to committing your changes, your edits still get saved to your computer. Before these changes end up in your

erences between two versions of a document. While
are the explicit checkpoints you create. A commit stores the
erences between the prior version of a document and the version at the time of committing.
also store the author of the commit, the time the commit was created, as well as a short message summarizing the changes.
After we commit our changes, we will see that the commit we created has a unique identifier associated with it called a SHA. A SHA is an identifier that is the product
, the prior commit's SHA, the commit message, the author's username, and the time at which the commit occurred. Sometimes in
s, we use the terms commit and SHA interchangeably. While a SHA is a 64 character string that describes a commit, you may sometimes see that SHA is used to describe an entire commit. In
we usually display only the first 4 to 8 characters of a SHA. This makes reading SHAs far easier to remember and keep track of.

A merge request is a remote representation of your branch. The reason they are called merge requests is because they are a way for your peers to review your changes and grant you permission to merge your changes into the
As you can see. In the merge request above, you can view the changes or the
of the branch. You and your peers can also comment on the changes made.
Normally, you wouldn't be able to merge a merge request without peer approval. There's usually some back and forth, where revisions are requested. Once you make your revisions locally, you must

Just as floro requires you to explicitly push changes to a branch, floro also requires you to explicitly pull changes as well.

You can think of pulling as being nearly synonymous with downloading. When a remote branch has changes that you do not have on your local version of the branch, you will see an option to pull down the changes for the branch.

branch locally. Our commits will still always be there but we no longer need the branch.

Merging is a term we threw around a bunch without really explaining what it is. We will cover merging in much greater depth in later parts of the documentation.
Merging is the process of taking the changes we made in our feature branch
and combining them with the changes made in the
branch by others. You don't have to do anything special but press the
to merge locally or in the case of a merge request, pressing
(as we showed in the example above).
Merging can occur both locally and remotely. Usually, when we merge locally, we are merging the
branch (or the base branch) into our feature-branch.
Sometimes we won't be able to merge our changes without resolving a conflict. Floro will warn us when there is a conflict. A conflict occurs when two
have incompatible changes. For example, if someone else were editing this paragraph simultaneously, whomever, merged their branch into the
branch second, would have to reconcile the conflict between the two paragraphs. We wouldn't be able to merge a merge request without addressing the merge conflicts locally first. Remote
must be conflict-free in order to be merged.
When we need to address a merge conflict we have to pull down the
branch. We do this by first first switching from our feature branch to the
branch and clicking pull remote. Next, we switch back to our feature-branch. Finally, we press
branch to compare our changes against. We should then see the option to
into our feature branch. From there we will be able to resolve the conflict and push up our resolved changes.
We will cover this entire process in much greater detail later. Hopefully, this is enough context to make sense of the process we went through above.

While we would love for our documentation to be comprehensive and easy enough for you to figure anything out on your own, please feel free to reach out to us on
if you can't figure out what you're looking for. If you see an area of the documentation that you believe you could improve upon, please write us on
Our product documentation is broken into the following sections and should be accessible to non-engineers.

Our developer documentation assumes familiarity with common web development practices and protocols. It may be beneficial to review the product documentation before diving into the developer documentation.

phrase.content: So now our question is actually pretty simple. We want to know if we can safely update version 1 to each new version N (version 2, version 3, and version 4). To do this we are going to ask a simple question, "
are the keys of version 1 all present in the subsequent version's key list?"
We're going to use two tiny pieces of math (set) notation here, "
If you've never seen these symbols before or need a quick refresher, they're quite simple.
A is a subset of B
For example, if A = {1, 2, 3} and B = {1, 2, 3, 4}, we would say that A is a subset of B, since 1, 2, and 3 are all present elements in B.
A is NOT a subset of B
For example, if A = {1, 2, 3} and B = {1, 3, 4}, we would say that A is
a subset of B, since the element 2 is not present in the elements of B.
So how does this connect back to generating code and type safety? Well if we know the
, we are able to perform type compatibility checks between
, simply by asking the question stated above.

state, we could safely deploy updated versions of our app to versions 2 or versions 3 with full confidence that we are not causing any bugs without having to recompile our entire application. If however, we were to swap out our content from version 1, to version 4, we would likely crash if a user ever visited a page calling the key

Floro wouldn't be much of a version control system if it didn't have diffs. But before explaining how diffs work in floro, it's best to take a step back and do a quick overview of diffing in general.

Diffing is the process of describing how one sequence transforms into a different sequence. Typically diffing involves finding the most concise way to transform between the two sequences. For sake of consistency, we will be discussing the two states of a diff as the "before" state and the "after" state.
The algorithm used for diffing is the
or LCS algorithm. There's a plethora of YouTube videos giving explanations of how to find the LCS for two sequences

. However, to help build intuition for the algorithm, we've provided you an LCS string calculator that delimits on characters. Feel free to type around and see how the LCS changes, when you change either of the strings.

The key thing to know about LCS, is that the opposite of the LCS is the diff, which makes sense when you think about it for a moment. The LCS tells us what is the same between two sequences, by comparing the LCS to the before sequence and after sequence, we can easily determine what was
The diff calculator below demonstrates this process.
Finally, we can return back to our Localization example to see how we can apply diffing to our plugin states.
The big philosophical question in diffing is how do you produce a meaningful diff?
Unfortunately, diffing documents is highly subjective to the task at hand. However, floro has a couple of tricks for making good diffs easy for plugin developers to create.

And that's the way that plugin diffing really works. While the user interfaces with the plugin via a user interface and alters the plugin's state tree through the GUI, the plugin interfaces with floro through its keys. In fact all that is communicated to a plugin about a diff, is which keys were removed and which keys were added.

The idea that all a document diff requires is two views, the before, and the after, as well as the keys that were removed from the before state and the keys that were added to the after state is the fundamental idea of document diffing.

If we look in our Translations data structure, you'll notice we abandoned our "Locale" property, which previously served as our primary key. We updated our data structure to now use a
We also set a cascading option "onDelete" to "delete", on our

property. The alternative cascading delete option value is "nullify". You probably can guess the difference at this point but if the "onDelete" value of a reference type is "delete", the set element containing that reference will be deleted, when the reference is deleted. For example, if we were to remove the Languages' element with the Code equal to "ZH" from the Languages list, our Translation element with the reference

would also be removed. However, if the "onDelete" property were set to "nullify", our Translation element would not be removed, we would be left will a null pointer though (ie. the value of LanguageReference would be set to equal to null). It is important to note that
nullifying our reference is not possible in this example, since the LanguageReference property is the primary key of the Translations set.
There's actually one more cascading behavior not commonly recognized in the world of relational databases that
expanding a set by the boundaries of another set
Imagine we wanted to add a new language (Spanish) to our plugin. If this were a relational database, we might add a new column "Spanish" to our Languages' table.
has a slightly different way of handling this relationship. We specify a property in our schema, that our set is a
This only works, when the primary key of our set is a reference to another set it can be bounded by.
cannot bind sets to other nested sets, only root-level
Once we add Spanish to our language list,
will automatically cascade all of the LocalizedKeys in the plugins state to include a reference to Spanish as well.
supports relationships between the substructures of a plugin's state. How it accomplishes this is through references. The keys of the
pairs are the actual pointer values in references. While this syntax could be used to point to any structure in a tree-state, it only makes sense to hold references to the elements of a set.

To further explain, we're going to build upon our prior example of our LocalizedKeys plugin. First we're going to refactor our schema to include a second set called "Languages". In this example, we're syntactically treating Languages as a separate plugin. However, it is perfectly fine to have multiple root level sets in the same plugin.

This is a really powerful trick, since what it allows us to do is make a certain assumption about our content. If we managed to deploy a version of our application that was built with "Version 1" of our

state, we could safely deploy updated versions of our app to versions 2 or versions 3 with full confidence that we are not causing any bugs without having to recompile our entire application. If however, we were to swap out our content from version 1, to version 4, we would likely crash if a user ever visited a page calling the key
" version of the app. We therefore would not ever deploy version 4.
By performing this simple set check, we've essentially done the work of a (

So now our question is actually pretty simple. We want to know if we can safely update version 1 to each new version N (version 2, version 3, and version 4). To do this we are going to ask a simple question, "
are the keys of version 1 all present in the subsequent version's key list?"
We're going to use two tiny pieces of math (set) notation here, "
If you've never seen these symbols before or need a quick refresher, they're quite simple.
A is a subset of B
For example, if A = {1, 2, 3} and B = {1, 2, 3, 4}, we would say that A is a subset of B, since 1, 2, and 3 are all present elements in B.
A is NOT a subset of B
For example, if A = {1, 2, 3} and B = {1, 3, 4}, we would say that A is
a subset of B, since the element 2 is not present in the elements of B.
So how does this connect back to generating code and type safety? Well if we know the
, we are able to perform type compatibility checks between plugin states, simply by asking the question stated above.

We will get to the version control side of things soon. We promise! The thing we're really interested in figuring out at this point is if there is anything we can universally guarantee about the code we generate from a generator. If we look back at our first example we can observe something kind of neat now. We can actually determine if an update to the plugin state, is type-compatible with our current content, by looking at the keys of our KV List alone.
To show this, we have to consider three types of changes.

phrase.content: has a few magic tricks up it's sleeve that allow it to do some pretty remarkable things. Before explaining the low-level details of how

Plugins are small UI applications directly managed by
repository as a global redux state store composed of a subset of plugin state stores. The goal of each plugin is to
do one thing and do it well

which describes the type of the content persisted by that plugin. Plugins are able to read and write to an external upstream plugin's store when the plugin requires the upstream plugin as a dependency. In this sense,
plugins behave both like applications as well as programming modules.

Plugins can also hold relationships between their internal store structures as well as the external structures of upstream plugins. Plugin developers can define cascading behaviors in a plugin's schema. This makes plugins particularly useful for centralizing relational content.
Ultimately, a plugin's state is meant to be consumed as input to a program called a
Generators transform the state of a plugin (usually into a type of

). This generated code can then be consumed by an application. A generator's output is language and environment agnostic. In the example below, we demonstrate how a Typescript output may be generated from the state of a simple localization plugin. It's important to note, there is nothing fundamental about

that requires the generated code to be Typescript or Javascript. Plugins and generators are not directly coupled. A plugin may have multiple generators and generators may take multiple plugin states as input. Generators can produce any type of output.
Plugin Schema -> Plugin State -> Generated Code

If you have any experience working on merge technology, you likely know that once you can describe a data structure as an ordered list or ordered set, you can merge it!

Repositories can be home to various types of content. You may use a

to host a content type that doesn't even exist yet. Maybe someone on your team will develop a special spreadsheet application just for you. The possibilities probably aren't endless but there's a lot of them. The key point is that repositories can host various content-types.
As you can see in the image above, repositories are composed of something called
are the constituents of repositories. They're small applications used for editing a certain content type.

erence between a plugin and a traditional web application, is

do not save your content to a
on your computer to save your content. Furthermore, the data saved by a plugin won't ever be sent to a
Presumably, you eventually want some of your edits to sync with someone else's changes. The really cool thing about
is that multiple authors, can work on the same content of a plugin, for the same
, at the same time and eventually end up with a controlled, and precise amalgam of their edits. For this to work out we need version control.
Have you ever saved a Google Doc or Microsoft Word file to something like "
only to realize two seconds later that you needed to make a change and then renamed your document to "
"My Document (Last time I was joking but this time I really mean it) Final.docx"
If you can relate, then you know the initial problem version control set out to solve over 50 years ago. On a fundamental level, all

If you mess something up, or need to revisit an earlier point of edits, you can always hop back in time to that checkpoint. You've likely experienced versioning features in applications like Google Docs, Microsoft Word, Notion, or even Figma.
While many applications have a sense of versioning, to get precise synchronization results we have to have a slightly
erent mental model of what a document really is. When we edited "
Prior to committing your changes, your edits still get saved to your computer. Before these changes end up in your
, we say the changes are a
. If you've ever worked on a document where you constantly had to save the file in order to not lose progress, you're familiar with what a
is. To be clear, even if you shut down
states are just impermanent until they are committed.
Going back to our checkpoint analogy,
erences between two versions of a document. While
are the explicit checkpoints you create. A commit stores the
erences between the prior version of a document and the version at the time of committing.
also store the author of the commit, the time the commit was created, as well as a short message summarizing the changes.
After we commit our changes, we will see that the commit we created has a unique identifier associated with it called a SHA. A SHA is an identifier that is the product
, the prior commit's SHA, the commit message, the author's username, and the time at which the commit occurred. Sometimes in
s, we use the terms commit and SHA interchangeably. While a SHA is a 64 character string that describes a commit, you may sometimes see that SHA is used to describe an entire commit. In
we usually display only the first 4 to 8 characters of a SHA. This makes reading SHAs far easier to remember and keep track of.
In the image above you may notice that there are two labels stemming from the same initial commit. These are what we call
The easiest way for me to conceptualize
it to think of them as subway lines. They may start off at the same initial station but ultimately they go off in

provide a way for you to experiment without fear of accidentally ruining your document. They also are a convenient way of allowing multiple members of the same team to work from the same starting point without stepping on each other's toes.
The goal of a branch is to be eventually merged back into its parent and then deleted.
As you can see in the above image. I'm currently working on a branch called "
the parent branch (also called the base branch) of my branch is called

Up until this point, everything we have done has been offline. When we switch the tab in the upper right corner, from
we now should see a prompt to create a merge request for our branch.

A merge request is a remote representation of your branch. The reason they are called merge requests is because they are a way for your peers to review your changes and grant you permission to merge your changes into the
As you can see. In the merge request above, you can view the changes or the
of the branch. You and your peers can also comment on the changes made.
Normally, you wouldn't be able to merge a merge request without peer approval. There's usually some back and forth, where revisions are requested. Once you make your revisions locally, you must
you make locally for them to appear in your merge request.
in this example, I have administrative access that allows me to merge my branch without requiring peer approval. When I press the button that says "
I will not be merging the changes on my
. The merged changes will be made in the
, I will not see the updated changes. Why is that?
Just as floro requires you to explicitly push changes to a branch, floro also requires you to explicitly pull changes as well.

You can think of pulling as being nearly synonymous with downloading. When a remote branch has changes that you do not have on your local version of the branch, you will see an option to pull down the changes for the branch.
In the image above, you can see the
option is available to us now. We should highlight we switched our local branch from
should be in sync. This is how version control allows us to collaborate with others, while being able to work independently and concurrently. If we want to, we can now delete the
branch locally. Our commits will still always be there but we no longer need the branch.
In the workflow we just described, we threw around the word branch kind of liberally. Technically we could say all
are created equal. In practice, there's a big distinction between two classes of
is what we would call a feature branch. Every

Generally speaking, you should only make changes to feature

or whatever is the default branch of your
The only interaction you should have with the

. There are some exceptions and a few other common interactions we will discuss later in the documentation.
Merging is a term we threw around a bunch without really explaining what it is. We will cover merging in much greater depth in later parts of the documentation.
Merging is the process of taking the changes we made in our feature branch
and combining them with the changes made in the
branch by others. You don't have to do anything special but press the
to merge locally or in the case of a merge request, pressing
(as we showed in the example above).
Merging can occur both locally and remotely. Usually, when we merge locally, we are merging the
branch (or the base branch) into our feature-branch.
Sometimes we won't be able to merge our changes without resolving a conflict. Floro will warn us when there is a conflict. A conflict occurs when two
have incompatible changes. For example, if someone else were editing this paragraph simultaneously, whomever, merged their branch into the
branch second, would have to reconcile the conflict between the two paragraphs. We wouldn't be able to merge a merge request without addressing the merge conflicts locally first. Remote
must be conflict-free in order to be merged.
When we need to address a merge conflict we have to pull down the
branch. We do this by first first switching from our feature branch to the
branch and clicking pull remote. Next, we switch back to our feature-branch. Finally, we press
branch to compare our changes against. We should then see the option to
into our feature branch. From there we will be able to resolve the conflict and push up our resolved changes.
We will cover this entire process in much greater detail later. Hopefully, this is enough context to make sense of the process we went through above.

一般来说，在编程中，我们认为颜色是红、绿、蓝三色值的组合。如果我们将红、绿、蓝视为自变量，就可以得到如下图所示的 schema。
这可能是一个有效的 schema，也是表示数据结构的有效方法。
从红色到黄色和品红色的变化是否应该自动解析为白色？可能不是，但也许这就是应用程序的预期行为。
要解决这个问题，我们可以选择不将每个变量视为独立变量，而是定义一个 schema，将红色、绿色和蓝色作为同一类别的一部分进行分组。十六进制代码自然就能做到这一点。这意味着红色、绿色和蓝色不能独立合并。这样，用户就必须选择黄色或洋红色，或者手动将颜色解析为其他颜色。
与传统关系型数据存储显著不同的地方。一个类别的属性是归一化还是去归一化，直接影响到类别及其子类别的合并和区分方式。
正如我们之前所说。Floro 的 KV 使用集合。我们说的“集合”，是指元素的 primary key 只能出现一次的列表。当 Floro 将 KV 集反序列化为树状状态时，如果遇到具有相同键的元素超过一次，它会跳过已经遇到的具有键的元素。

技术题外话：Floro 实际上也支持数组结构，但在序列化过程中，它们实际上被视为集合。在 Floro 中，数组和集合的主要区别在于数组元素的主键是其索引。我们会在进行 diffing 和合并操作前移除数组元素的索引，这使得基于 LCS 的算法仍能正常工作，因为重复值及其普通性是使用 LCS 进行 diffing 和合并时正确工作的必要条件
如果你还记得我们在前面的章节中说过，
"Floro 并没有真正把 Plugin 状态看成是树状态"。
我们撒了个小谎......抱歉。Floro 在合并两个 KV 序列之后，会对合并结果进行级联。这就是 Floro 如何保证一致性的，尽管它是在盲目地合并数据结构，除了它们的 schema 之外，它对其他数据结构一无所知。虽然你可以为 git 编写自定义的
，但在一个非结构化的版本控制系统中执行级联规则是不可能的（如果不是不可能，那也是不切实际，还不如

如果我们不对上图中的合并结果进行级联，我们最终会得到一个不一致的状态。这也意味着，许多在纯文本版本控制系统中会产生冲突的合并，在结构化后往往不会产生冲突。
结构和合并是紧密联系在一起的。
这对 git 而言不是问题的原因是，当冲突出现时，git 要依靠程序员来解决它的不一致性。
我们并不主张任何人停止使用 git。git、Mercurial和Fossil对于代码和纯文本来说都非常棒。对于纯文本使用情况，Floro将是一个糟糕的工具。Floro旨在与
版本控制系统对接，而非取代它们。

through its keys. In fact all that is communicated to a plugin about a diff, is which keys were removed and which keys were added.

The idea that all a document diff requires is two views, the before, and the after, as well as the keys that were removed from the before state and the keys that were to the after state is the fundamental idea of document diffing.

In the next section we discuss merging and data granularity. One key thing to know at this point, is that if something can be diffed (meaningfully) then it can also be merged (meaningfully)... even when conflicts arise.

wouldn't be much of a version control system if it didn't have diffs. But before explaining how diffs work in
, it's best to take a step back and do a quick overview of diffing in general.

Diffing is the process of describing how one sequence transforms into a different sequence. Typically diffing involves finding the most concise way to transform between the two sequences. For sake of consistency, we will be discussing the two states of a diff as the "before" state and the "after" state. Although there is no real direction in diffing.

The above image illustrates how cascading enforces bounded sets. Since Translations are bounded by Languages (due to the primary key of Translations being a reference to Languages), we can guarantee that for every LocalizationKey element, for each of its Translations element there will always be an element with a reference to each Language element. This becomes particularly important when we get into merging states, which necessitates cascading states.
Conceptually, we've now created for ourselves, what is essentially an excel spreadsheet.

If you're overwhelmed by this change, don't be. It's actually not nearly as complicated as it may look at first glance. If we look in our Translations data structure, you'll notice we abandoned our "Locale" property, which previously served as our primary key. We updated our data structure to now use a
We also set a cascading option "onDelete" to "delete", on our

property. The alternative cascading delete option value is "nullify". You probably can guess the difference at this point but if the "onDelete" value of a reference type is "delete", the set element containing that reference will be deleted, when the reference is deleted. For example, if we were to remove the Languages' element with the Code equal to "ZH" from the Languages list, our Translation element with the reference

would also be removed. However, if the "onDelete" property were set to "nullify", our Translation element would not be removed, we would be left will a null pointer though (ie. the value of LanguageReference would be set to equal to null). It is important to note that
nullifying our reference is not possible in this example, since the LanguageReference property is the primary key of the Translations set.

expanding a set by the boundaries of another set

To further explain, we're going to build upon our prior example of our LocalizedKeys plugin. First we're going to refactor our schema to include a second set called "Languages". In this example, we're syntactically treating Languages as a separate plugin. However, it is perfectly fine to have multiple root level sets in the same plugin.

This is a really powerful trick, since what it allows us to do is make a certain assumption about our content. If we managed to deploy a version of our application that was built with "Version 1" of our

state, we could safely deploy updated versions of our app to versions 2 or versions 3 with full confidence that we are not causing any bugs without having to recompile our entire application. If however, we were to swap out our content from version 1, to version 4, we would likely crash if a user ever visited a page calling the key
" version of the app. We therefore would not ever deploy version 4.
By performing this simple set check, we've essentially done the work of a (

So now our question is actually pretty simple. We want to know if we can safely update version 1 to each new version N (version 2, version 3, and version 4). To do this we are going to ask a simple question, "
are the keys of version 1 all present in the subsequent version's key list?"
We're going to use two tiny pieces of math (set) notation here, "
If you've never seen these symbols before or need a quick refresher, they're quite simple.
A is a subset of B
For example, if A = {1, 2, 3} and B = {1, 2, 3, 4}, we would say that A is a subset of B, since 1, 2, and 3 are all present elements in B.
A is NOT a subset of B
For example, if A = {1, 2, 3} and B = {1, 3, 4}, we would say that A is
a subset of B, since the element 2 is not present in the elements of B.

Plugins are small UI applications directly managed by
repository as a global redux state store composed of a subset of plugin state stores. The goal of each plugin is to
do one thing and do it well

which describes the type of the content persisted by that plugin. Plugins are able to read and write to an external upstream plugin's store when the plugin requires the upstream plugin as a dependency. In this sense,
plugins behave both like applications as well as programming modules.

Plugins can also hold relationships between their internal store structures as well as the external structures of upstream plugins. Plugin developers can define cascading behaviors in a plugin's schema. This makes plugins particularly useful for centralizing relational content.
Ultimately, a plugin's state is meant to be consumed as input to a program called a
Generators transform the state of a plugin (usually into a type of

). This generated code can then be consumed by an application. A generator's output is language and environment agnostic. In the example below, we demonstrate how a Typescript output may be generated from the state of a simple localization plugin. It's important to note, there is nothing fundamental about

that requires the generated code to be Typescript or Javascript. Plugins and generators are not directly coupled. A plugin may have multiple generators and generators may take multiple plugin states as input. Generators can produce any type of output.
